content.title: Gender Equality And Sustainable Energy Finance
content.intro: M4: Financing Just Energy Transition | Chapter 5 | Lesson 2

content.text: Lesson 2 Overview

This lesson examines the systemic barriers women face in accessing climate and energy finance, emphasizing the role of intersectionality in amplifying disparities. It explores how overlapping identities—such as gender, ethnicity, socioeconomic status, and disability—impact access to financial resources, leadership opportunities, and energy technologies. Women from marginalized groups, including Indigenous and rural women, face unique challenges like lack of collateral, discriminatory lending practices, and underrepresentation in decision-making processes. The lesson highlights inclusive solutions, such as gender-responsive financial instruments, capacity-building initiatives, and culturally sensitive policies, to address these inequities. It also underscores the importance of partnerships and data-driven approaches in creating equitable and sustainable energy finance systems.

concepts.body: Intersectionality is a framework for understanding how various social identities, such as race, gender, class, and sexuality, intersect and interact to create unique experiences of discrimination and privilege.

concepts.title: risk-sharing mechanisms
concepts.body: Risk-sharing mechanisms are strategies or arrangements that distribute the financial risks associated with a project or investment among multiple parties, reducing the burden on any single entity.

concepts.title: targeted funding√™
concepts.body: Targeted funding refers to financial resources allocated specifically for a particular project, initiative, or purpose, often aimed at addressing specific needs or goals within a community or sector.

content.text: Energy finance plays a crucial role in enabling transitions to sustainable and low-carbon energy systems globally. However, the prevailing structures of energy finance often fail to account for gendered differences in energy access, decision-making, and resource distribution. This oversight exacerbates existing inequalities and undermines the potential for inclusive and sustainable development. Women, who represent a significant portion of those disproportionately impacted by energy poverty and climate change, often face systemic barriers in accessing financial resources and participating in energy-related decision-making processes. Globally, more than 750 million people lack access to electricity, and over 2.3 billion still rely on harmful fuels for cooking—a burden disproportionately borne by women. These energy deficits not only reinforce gender inequities but also limit women’s potential to act as agents of change in energy transitions. Women’s roles as primary energy users in households and as leaders in community-driven energy initiatives uniquely position them to contribute to sustainable energy development. Yet, their participation in energy finance remains minimal due to structural barriers such as lack of access to credit, underrepresentation in leadership, and gender-biased financial instruments.

content.intro: M4: Financing Just Energy Transition | Chapter 5 | Lesson 2 | Part 1
content.title: Part 1: Gender Gap in Energy Finance

content.intro: M4: Financing Just Energy Transition | Chapter 4 | Lesson 2 | Part 1 | A
content.title: A. Inequitable Financing Flows

content.text: The distribution of climate and energy finance reflects systemic inequities:
Skewed Allocation

Women are disproportionately impacted by climate change due to existing structural inequalities. Moreover, women farmers receive just 10% of total aid for agriculture, forestry, and fishing, despite their critical role in food production and climate-smart practices. This exclusion from financial support undermines women's capacity to adapt to climate impacts and limits their participation in building resilient communities.
Neglect of Small-Scale Beneficiaries

Women represent the majority of those living in poverty, comprising 43% of the agricultural workforce in emerging economies and producing up to 80% of food in Sub-Saharan Africa. However, in 2019, just 2% of global climate finance reached small farmers, local communities, and Indigenous groups—many of whom are women.
Lack of Gender-Responsive Funding

In 2019, only 0.04% of climate-focused Official Development Assistance (ODA) had gender equality as its principal objective. Similarly, in 2022, only 3% of ODA on climate integrated gender considerations, and just 11% of adaptation projects globally were tagged as gender-responsive
Lack of gender-disaggregated data

There is a significant lack of gender-disaggregated data in climate finance, which makes it difficult to assess the impact of investments on women and marginalized groups. Without robust tracking mechanisms, the effectiveness of gender-responsive initiatives remains unclear . Existing monitoring frameworks often prioritize economic metrics over social or gender outcomes, undermining the visibility of gender inequities.

content.intro: M4: Financing Just Energy Transition | Chapter 4 | Lesson 1 | Part 3 | B
content.title: B. Lack of Access To Credit

content.text: Women face systemic barriers to accessing credit and financial services, including discriminatory lending practices and limited land ownership for collateral. Access to finance is another significant challenge. Women often lack collateral and face discriminatory lending practices, resulting in higher interest rates and shorter loan terms compared to men. Globally, 80% of women-owned businesses are financially underserved, leaving them unable to transition to sustainable practices or invest in green technologies. Furthermore, Indigenous and marginalized women face additional barriers, with research showing that non-Indigenous women in Bolivia are twice as likely to secure loans compared to their Indigenous counterparts.
Collateral Requirements
Women own less than 20% of the world’s land, which limits their ability to secure loans. Without collateral, access to formal credit becomes nearly impossible for many women .
Discriminatory Lending Practices:

Institutions often impose stricter terms and higher interest rates on women. For instance, female entrepreneurs are required to provide more stringent collateral than male counterparts, despite evidence showing that women are reliable borrowers .
Limited Financial Inclusion

80% of women-owned businesses globally remain unserved or underserved by financial institutions. This exclusion is particularly significant in developing countries, where women play a critical role in energy-related small businesses and household energy solutions

content.intro: M4: Financing Just Energy Transition | Chapter 4 | Lesson 1 | Part 3 | C
content.title: C. Challenges with D4E tool

content.text: Women remain underrepresented in leadership roles within energy finance institutions and policy-making bodies. For instance, only 7% of startup founders in the energy sector are women, reflecting systemic biases in the industry
Board Representation
Female participation on the boards of major climate funds averages only 22%, severely limiting their influence in shaping energy policies and finance allocations .
Policy Influence

Women are underrepresented in global and national energy policymaking bodies, often due to entrenched societal norms that prioritize male leadership. This underrepresentation results in a lack of gender-responsive strategies in energy finance .
Grassroots Leadership
While women lead community-level energy resilience projects, they often lack access to platforms where decisions about resource allocation and project funding are made
Intersectionality And Gender Inequality

Intersectionality highlights how overlapping identities—such as gender, race, ethnicity, socioeconomic status, and disability—can amplify disparities in access to climate and energy finance. Women who belong to marginalized groups, such as Indigenous women, rural entrepreneurs, or those with disabilities, face compounded barriers. These may include exclusion from formal financial systems, lack of collateral due to discriminatory land ownership practices, or inaccessibility of energy solutions tailored to their needs. For example, rural women often manage household energy but struggle to access credit or technology, while Indigenous women may encounter language barriers and systemic bias when applying for funding. Similarly, women with disabilities face heightened risks during climate-induced disasters, yet their specific needs are frequently overlooked in finance policies. Addressing these intersecting vulnerabilities requires inclusive solutions, such as targeted grants, accessible infrastructure, and decision-making processes that include diverse voices.Incorporating intersectionality into climate and energy finance ensures that strategies and policies are inclusive, targeted, and equitable.

For instance, Indigenous women, who are frequently excluded from formal financial systems due to language barriers or discriminatory land ownership practices, require tailored financial instruments such as culturally sensitive grant schemes. Similarly, rural women, who are often responsible for household energy management, need accessible microloans and training programs to adopt sustainable energy technologies. Women with disabilities, who face unique challenges in accessing infrastructure and services, should benefit from inclusive designs and decision-making processes that prioritize accessibility and safety. Incorporating intersectionality into climate and energy finance ensures that strategies and policies are inclusive, targeted, and equitable, moving away from one-size-fits-all approaches that often overlook the diverse and overlapping challenges faced by marginalized groups

content.intro: M4: Financing Just Energy Transition | Chapter 4 | Lesson 1 | Part 3 | D
content.title: D. Biased Cultural and Social Norms

content.text: Cultural and societal norms significantly influence women’s access to and participation in climate finance.
Entrenched Gender Biases

Women are often excluded from financial systems due to societal norms or nepotism that undervalue their contributions to economic and environmental activities. For example, women’s unpaid domestic labor and informal work are not considered in eligibility criteria for financial programs . Stereotypes about women’s capabilities and financial reliability lead to discriminatory lending practices, further marginalizing them.
Patriarchal Land Ownership Systems:

Women own less than 20% of the world’s land, which severely limits their ability to provide collateral for loans. In many regions, land ownership laws and customary practices favor men, restricting women's financial autonomy . This lack of asset ownership disproportionately affects rural women who rely on land for agricultural and energy-related activities, crucial in climate resilience strategies.

content.intro: M4: Financing Just Energy Transition | Chapter 4 | Lesson 3 | Part 2
content.title: Part 2: Addressing Gender Gaps in Climate and Energy Finance"

content.text: Integrating Gender into Climate Finance Frameworks

Policy Inclusion Incorporate gender considerations into Nationally Determined Contributions (NDCs) and climate finance strategies. Notably, 97 updated NDCs now include gender equality considerations, a significant increase from 49 in the first generation. Additionally, 21 countries have highlighted the importance of women's access to finance in their climate strategies, compared to none in previous plans. UNFCCC Gender-Responsive Budgeting Implement budgeting processes that allocate funds specifically for gender-responsive climate initiatives, ensuring that financial resources address the unique needs of women and marginalized groups. Moreover, Sustainable energy finance instruments must integrate gender considerations at every stage, from planning to implementation . One example is the National Energy and Climate Plans (NECPs) that are mandatory frameworks for EU Member States and candidate countries to outline how they will meet the EU’s 2030 climate and energy goals, including emissions reduction, renewables, and energy efficiency. Updated NECP guidelines require the integration of gender considerations, including assessing policy impacts on different genders, ensuring inclusive participation, and promoting equality in the energy transition.
Enhancing Women's Access to Climate Finance

Innovative Financial Mechanisms Develop tools such as impact investing and gender bonds to provide businesses with access to credit designed for women. Mainstreaming gender policies can encourage women's participation across asset classes, supporting energy access in emerging economies. Capacity Building Offer training and support to women entrepreneurs in the energy sector to improve their business management skills, energy use efficiency, and access to new business opportunities and financing. For example, initiatives like the Women's Energy Entrepreneurship initiative have been instrumental in empowering female entrepreneurs.
Promoting Women's Leadership in Climate Decision-Making

Inclusive Governance Ensure women's representation in climate finance decision-making bodies to incorporate diverse perspectives and needs. Programs that support women's roles in energy decision-making at household, community, and national levels are crucial for inclusive policy development. Networking and Mentorship Establish platforms for women in the energy sector to share experiences, access mentorship, and build professional networks, fostering leadership and collaboration.
Community Engagement

Targeted Funding Increase financial commitments to energy projects with specific gender equality objectives. Community Engagement Support local organizations that empower women as clean energy entrepreneurs, recognizing their role in expanding energy access and promoting sustainable practices. Initiatives like Solar Sister in Africa, take an innovative approach to social enterprise and empowers women with economic opportunities through entrepreneurship, leading to enhanced energy access and poverty alleviation. It combines the breakthrough potential of portable solar technology with a women driven direct sales network to bring light, hope and opportunity to a range of communities without reliable electricity access The initiative was implemented in Uganda, Rwanda and South Sudan, brining the benefits of solar power to more than 31,000 Africans.
Monitoring and Accountability Community Engagement

Data Collection Gender-disaggregated data to assess the impact of climate finance on different genders, is enabling informed decision-making and policy adjustments. Transparent Reporting Mandate regular reporting on the gender impacts of climate finance initiatives to ensure accountability and continuous improvement.

Implementing gender equality strategies requires collaboration among governments, financial institutions, civil society, and the private sector to create an inclusive climate finance ecosystem that empowers women and addresses gender disparities effectively. Furthermore mainstreaming gender in programmes and projects and designing gender-responsive activities are important gender considerations in programme that ensure and promote gender quality and women’s empowerment.

content.title: Key Takeaways
content.intro: If you only have space to remember 3 things:

takeaways.title: Women, especially those from marginalized groups, face systemic barriers in accessing climate and energy finance due to discriminatory practices, lack of collateral, and underrepresentation in leadership roles.

Addressing these challenges requires inclusive solutions such as culturally sensitive financial tools, capacity-building initiatives, and gender-responsive policies that empower women as key agents in energy transitions.

Promoting equitable partnerships, targeted funding, and robust data collection ensures that climate finance strategies effectively address intersectional gender inequalities, fostering sustainable and inclusive development.
